description: From Middle English hukster, probably of Low German or Dutch origin, from Middle Low German höken (“to peddle”) or Middle Dutch hokester, itself from hoeken (“to peddle”), all from Proto-Germanic *huk-; compare hawkster.

entries.meaning: A peddler or hawker, who sells small items, either door-to-door, from a stall, or in the street.
examples: drive those china hucksters from the doors

entries.meaning: Somebody who sells things in an aggressive or showy manner.
One who deceptively sells fraudulent products.
Somebody who writes advertisements for radio or television.

verbs.description: huckster (third-person singular simple present hucksters, present participle huckstering, simple past and past participle huckstered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To haggle, to wrangle, or to bargain.
(transitive) To sell or offer goods from place to place, to peddle.
(transitive) To promote or sell goods in an aggressive, showy manner.
